meanings.definition: The belief in the inherent superiority of one's own ethnic group.
meanings.sent1: Some people's ethnocentrisms make them think their culture is the best.
meanings.sent2: Ethnocentrisms can lead to misunderstandings and conflicts between different ethnic groups.
meanings.sent3: His ethnocentrisms were so strong that he believed his way of life was the only correct one.
meanings.sent4: She wore her ethnocentrisms like a crown, looking down on anyone different from her.
meanings.sent5: The professor's ethnocentrisms colored his view of history, making him biased in his teachings.

meanings.definition: The tendency to view other cultures through the lens of one's own cultural norms.
meanings.sent1: Ethnocentrisms can prevent people from appreciating the diversity of other cultures.
meanings.sent2: It's important to be aware of our ethnocentrisms when interacting with people from different backgrounds.
meanings.sent3: Her ethnocentrisms sometimes led to funny misunderstandings when trying new foods.
meanings.sent4: Breaking free from ethnocentrisms is like removing colored glasses to see the world in its true hues.
meanings.sent5: The movie highlighted the dangers of ethnocentrisms by showing how it can lead to conflict and division.

meanings.definition: The practice of judging other cultures as inferior to one's own.
meanings.sent1: Ethnocentrisms can blind us to the beauty and value of diverse cultural practices.
meanings.sent2: His ethnocentrisms made him unable to appreciate the richness of traditions different from his own.
meanings.sent3: Their ethnocentrisms were so extreme that they thought all other cultures were primitive.
meanings.sent4: Letting go of ethnocentrisms is like opening a door to a world of understanding and acceptance.
meanings.sent5: The novel portrayed the destructive nature of ethnocentrisms by showing how it can lead to isolation and ignorance.
